title: Use correct encoding when fetching non-UTF-8 site metadata
body:
When the site metadata is fetched, the default assumption is that it will be encoded in UTF-8, but this is not always the case. The result is that the metadata will be displayed in the frontend as garbled characters. This PR adds an additional check on the `charset` property of the fetched page if present, and will re-decode the fetched bytes with the specified encoding if possible. Should an unknown encoding be specified, it will fall back to the original UTF-8 data.

Fixes #1858 

**NOTE**: An unrelated fix is also included, as the website in the original issue started its response with a blank line before the DOCTYPE declaration. For this purpose, `trim_start()` was added to the HTML parsing.

title: Case-insensitive webfinger response. Fixes #1955 & #1986
body:
**Case-insensitive webfinger response**

- The webfinger regex in crates/utils/src/settings/mod.rs has been modified so that the server will no longer reject requests containing A-Z characters. 

**Case-insensitive database search**  

- The [sql_function “lower”](http://docs.diesel.rs/diesel/macro.sql_function.html) has been added to  crates/db_schema/src/lib.rs. This function allows one to perform a database searches applying lower(column) operations with diesel. 

- In /crates/db_schema/Cargo.toml, the [lib] block has been updated to be able to import the lib.rs functions.

- The lower function is loaded by lemmy/crates/db_schema/src/impls/person.rs and lemmy/crates/db_schema/src/impls/community.rs, and used to perform a case-insensitive database searches via find_by_name and read_from_name, respectively. This allows the webfinger response to be case insensitive.  

**Include uppercase characters in the API_tests**

- The randomString generation function in api_tests/src/shared.ts has been updated to include uppercase characters when running tests.



**Field tests**

The user Sal can now be viewed in lemmy.ml:
https://lemmy.ml/u/Sal@mander.xyz

The following curls will trigger the correct webfinger responses for the user Sal and for the community main. 



curl "https://mander.xyz/.well-known/webfinger?resource=acct:SaL@mander.xyz"
curl "https://mander.xyz/.well-known/webfinger?resource=acct:sal@mander.xyz"

curl "https://mander.xyz/.well-known/webfinger?resource=acct:main@mander.xyz"
curl "https://mander.xyz/.well-known/webfinger?resource=acct:MAIN@mander.xyz"

I have performed mastodon searches to fetch content as well, and the searches are now case-insensitive. 


This commit would replace  #2000. LemmyNet/lemmy-ui#525 can be reversed as users should be able to use uppercase names without problem. Issues #1955 and #1986 will be solved.

title: Opentelemetry
body:
This adds an optional OTLP exporter to lemmy to expose tracing spans as opentelemetry data to be consumed by OTLP-compatible collectors

Additionally, it adds the official opentelemetry collector and the jaeger all-in-one container to the development docker compose to improve visibility in development

No changes were made to the production docker-compose file because I'm not sure a good way to ship an OTLP collector that will work in most environments.

title: Trying out an upgraded version of html5ever. #1964
Adding min setup password length to the docs. Fixes #1989
Remove awc
body:
Followup to https://github.com/LemmyNet/lemmy/pull/1978

Replaces awc with reqwest for interacting with pict-rs. This further limits the number of HTTP clients in the application. At this point, I believe every HTTP request is made by the same reqwest client, and therefore now shares a single connection pool.

title: Consolidate reqwest clients, use reqwest-middleware for tracing
body:
This change shares the `reqwest::Client` created in main throughout the whole app, rather than letting individual pieces create their own clients. This way, the app can configure the client in a single place, and share a connection pool.

It also wraps the `reqwest::Client` in a `request_middleware::ClientWithMiddleware` in order to allow further customization of the client. As presented in this PR, the client is instrumented with a `tracing` middleware. In the future, lemmy could be configured to export opentelemetry spans, and this middleware will allow forwarding the trace ID from lemmy to pict-rs for full distributed tracing.

title: Use once_cell instead of lazy_static
body:
One less macro, which also means that things like clippy and IDEs work a bit better with the code. For example, some of the regexes were unused, but we never got any warning because it was in the macro.

[once_cell is also going to be included in the standard library](https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/issues/74465). That means we will have one dependency less.

title: Adding unique constraint for activity ap_id. Fixes #1878
Change NodeInfo `links` to an array
body:
NodeInfo spec[1] says that _.well-known/nodeinfo_ is a JSON Resource
Descriptor (JRD) document. That is specified in RFC 7033, where §4.4[2]
mandates that `links` is an array.

1. https://nodeinfo.diaspora.software/protocol.html
2. https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/rfc7033#section-4.4

title: Dont announce comments, edited posts to Pleroma/Mastodon followers
body:
It was mentioned that the current Lemmy behaviour of announcing all new and edited posts/comments to Pleroma and Mastodon followers might be too noisy. So here is a PR which changes it so that only new posts are announced to them. For us this doesnt make a difference, as we are specifically sending these activities for compatibility with Mastodon/Pleroma. 

Note that these users wont receive any comments from Lemmy then, unless it is a mention. Lemmy also doesnt provide a `replies` collection on posts or comments for the time being. So let me know what you prefer @lanodan @gargron @ClearlyClaire.

title: Implement rate limits on comments
body: Comments are often a target for spammers, particularly because they are not rate limited whereas posts etc are. Comment rate limits are already present on e.g. Reddit, and we have found them indispensable since we implemented them.

title: Pleroma compatibility
body:
When opening a url like `https://ds9.lemmy.ml/u/nutomic@fedi.absturztau.be`, Lemmy was trying to construct the url to fetch locally. That doesnt work with other software which has different urls, so we need to use webfinger.

The other problem was that Pleroma puts a lot more stuff in the activity `to` field, so we need to handle that by replacing the fixed size array with a Vec (which allows any number of elements). Makes the code less elegant unfortunately.

Third commit is a hack, because in a Create/Note, Lemmy expects the Note to have a @context field, but activitypub only requires that field on the outermost object (the create in this case). I have to make a proper fix for this before 0.14, but this should be enough for testing.

You probably have to `rm target` and then run tests in order to install the new commit hook.

title: Add both (De)Serialize to all models
body: As discussed in the dev Matrix channel, I'm adding both `Serialize` and `Deserialize` to all models, so that clients can pull them from these crates instead of implementing everything themselves.

title: Refactor apub
body:
I wasnt planning to make this huge refactor, but one thing led to another and here we are. 

I cant even find the important parts of code to comment, so i will try to explain here:

- Remove DeletableApubObject trait: this was just a temporary thing and has been merged into ApubObject now
- Merge crates db_schema and db_queries: originally i moved FromApub and ToApub to the library, which means that the impl has to be in the same crate as the struct definition. So it made sense to merge both of these and put all the impls together. Its also something we discussed before, and doesnt have any negative impact on compilation time
- Major refactor, adding newtypes for apub crate: After the previous commit, it was necessary to have part of the apub code (impl ToApub and impl FromApub) in lemmy_db_schema, which just doesnt make much sense. So instead i added some newtype wrappers, so that the code can stay in lemmy_apub

The main thing thats left to move to the library is ObjectId, but that looks tricky due to generics, so i will do it later.

Please dont squash.

title: Adding honeypot to user and post creation. Fixes #1802
Move code to apub library
body:
I moved a couple more things to the library (traits ApubObject, ActorType, also http signature handling and activity sending queue). This means that I had to move some trait impls into the db_schema crate (because impls can only be defined in the same crate with the struct, or in the same crate as the trait definition). 

Following this, I think we can also merge the crates db_schema and db_queries again. They have to be compiled one after the other, so it doesnt help with compilation time at all to split the code this way. 

There is still some apub code which needs to be moved to the library, mainly ObjectId, receive_activity(), FromApub, ToApub. I will take care of those in a later PR.

title: Rewrite fetcher
body: These are all internal changes in the apub crate, and shouldnt affect the behaviour (except for bug fixes). The code is much cleaner now, and doesnt implement the same logic multiple times. This is also necessary so that we can move it to the library later.
